data.title: Exploring Thin Film Lithium Niobate (TFLN)
data.meta_description: The article below is duplicated from its original PDF version — a section in the 12th issue of the monthly "Physics Matters" newsletter — for greater ease of scrolling/reading on handheld devices. Check out other interesting highlights in the newsletter too.
data.text:
LinkedIn and 3rd parties use essential and non-essential cookies to provide, secure, analyze and improve our Services, and to show you relevant ads (including professional and job ads) on and off LinkedIn. Learn more in our Cookie Policy.

Select Accept to consent or Reject to decline non-essential cookies for this use. You can update your choices at any time in your settings.

The article below is duplicated from its original PDF version — a section in the 12th issue of the monthly "Physics Matters" newsletter — for greater ease of scrolling/reading on handheld devices. Check out other interesting highlights in the newsletter too.

Often motivated by their outstanding piezoelectric, ferroelectric and electro-optical properties, lithium niobate (LiNbO3, LN) thin films are widely studied and explored for their potential applications in acoustic and photonic devices. For example, LN thin films with high electromechanical coupling coefficients could offer performance improvements in acoustic resonators for radio frequency filters — crucial for high speed and low latency wireless communication. LN thin films have also risen to the forefront of chip-scale nonlinear optics research, while inspiring a wealth of opportunities for the development of novel signal processing devices, quantum interconnects, power-efficient light amplification/generation and so on.

With the above perspectives, we are excited to announce a recent review in the World Scientific Annual Review of Functional Materials (WSARFM), focusing on the developments, challenges and key learning points in the fabrication and direct growth methods of high quality LN thin films. Read now and bookmark for essential reference, while it is freely accessible to all users:
